law.catch_line: If an access contract provides for access over a period of time, the following rules apply:...

text.section:
If an access contract provides for access over a period of time, the following rules apply:
The licensee's rights of access are to the information as modified and made commercially available by the licensor from time to time during that period.
A change in the content of the information is a breach of contract only if the change conflicts with an express term of the agreement.
Unless it is subject to a contractual use term, information obtained by the licensee is free of any use restriction other than a restriction resulting from the informational rights of another person or other law.
Access must be available:
At times and in a manner conforming to the express terms of the agreement; and
To the extent not expressly stated in the agreement, at times and in a manner reasonable for the particular type of contract in light of the ordinary standards of the business, trade, or industry.

In an access contract that gives the licensee a right of access at times substantially of its own choosing during agreed periods, an occasional failure to have access available during those times is not a breach of contract if it is:
Consistent with ordinary standards of the business, trade, or industry for the particular type of contract; or
Caused by:
Scheduled downtime;
Reasonable needs for maintenance;
Reasonable periods of failure of equipment, computer programs, or communications; or
Events reasonably beyond the licensor's control, and the licensor exercises such commercially reasonable efforts as the circumstances require.
